EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
			 
Item:  8.02
TO:
Board of Trustees
							 
FROM:  
							 
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
						 
						 
PREPARED BY:
Marcus Battle, Associate Superintendent of Business Services, and Donna Bertrand, C.P.M., Contracts Administration Coordinator, Julie Kasberger, Director of General Services, and Duggan Kerney, President, CPRS
						 
						 
SUBJECT:
Presentation, Discussion and/or Action of Fixed Assets and Inventory Report
			 
			 
The District contracted with California Property Record Systems (CPRS) to conduct an inventory of all district fixed assets.  In this case, fixed assets include all furniture and equipment valued over $500.00 at time of purchase (including taxes and shipping costs).  This is required by our liability and property insurance carrier and for compliance with the State Education Code. 
			 
Attached is a copy of the results of the audit, including recommendations for further implementation by Administration.
			 
			 
FISCAL IMPACT:
Not Applicable
			 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Not Applicable
			 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees receive the fixed asset inventory report.

EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
Item:  9.01
	 
	 
TO:
Board of Trustees
				 
				 
FROM:  
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
				 
				 
PREPARED BY:
Juan Cruz, Assistant Superintendent of Instructional Services and Kirsten King Director of Instructional Services
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Hold Public Hearing at Approximately 6:10 p.m. on the Provisions of the Charter School Petition of B. Roberto Cruz Leadership Academy to Consider the Level of Support for Each Petition by Teachers Employed by the District, Other Employees of the District, and Parents
BACKGROUND
	 
Pursuant to Education Code 47605 a public hearing is required within 30 days following the submission of a charter school petition to the district.  The petition was submitted to the district on December 11, 2012.  
	 
During the public hearing, the Governing Board of the school district shall consider the level of support for the petition by the teachers employed by the district, other employees of the district and parents.  The Governing Board shall either grant or deny the charters within 60 days of receipt of the petition.  The Governing Board shall make their determination at the February 14, 2013 Board Meeting.
	 
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
To Be Determined
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
To Be Determined
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
Hold public hearing to consider level of support for the petition submitted by B. Roberto Cruz Leadership Academy.

items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
	 
Item:  9.03
	 
TO:
Board of Trustees
					 
FROM:
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
					 
					 
PREPARED BY:
Cari Vaeth, Director, Human Resources
					 
SUBJECT:
Hold Public Hearing at Approximately 6:20 p.m. Regarding the Proposed Adoption of the Initial Proposal for the Successor Contract: From East Side Union High School District to East Side Teachers Association
	 
	 
The East Side Union High School District presents the following initial proposal to the East Side Teachers Association for the 2013-2014 school year.  Pursuant to Government Code §3547 the District’s initial proposal must be presented to the public in open session at a public meeting.
	 
The District continues to acknowledge and appreciate the contributions made to its mission and programs by its certificated employees, and continues to seek the utilization of equitable and collaborative methods of addressing the needs of the students, parents and employees of the East Side Union High School District.  Accordingly, the District initially proposes to continue the language of the present agreement for the 
2013-2014 school year except as modified in a manner consistent with the matters and issues described below.
	 
The District continues to experience severe financial constraints arising from a variety of factors.  The District views financial issues in the context of keeping the District solvent, maintaining the legally required reserves, and preserving the quality education for the students of the District.  Given the above, the District proposes the following areas for negotiations: Adjustments/reductions in total compensation which includes salary and benefits; reduction of work year, and class size; contract language amendments to Articles 6, 7, 11, 14, 29, 30, Appendix A and Appendix C.
	 
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Various
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
To be negotiated
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
Administration recommends that the Board sunshine and accept any comment on the District’s initial proposal to the East Side Teachers Association.

items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
	 
Item:  11.02
	 
	 
TO:
Board of Trustees
				 
				 
FROM: 
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Discussion and/or Action regarding Superintendent to become a Fellow of the American Leadership Forum - Silicon Valley as a Member of the Single Issue Education Class of 2013
	 
	 
	 
ALF – Silicon Valley was founded in 1988 based on the first American Leadership Forum chapter founded in Houston by Joseph Jaworski. His vision, outlined in the 1996 bestselling book, Synchronicity: The Inner Path to Leadership, was to establish an organization dedicated to bringing together leaders from diverse sectors of the community to explore leadership philosophies, increase their capacity and strengthen their commitment to work together on public issues.
	 
ALF has evolved over the past two and a half decades, attracting many of Silicon Valley's most influential leaders from all sectors. Today, ALF is on the radical edge of 21st century leadership and community change theory and practice. The program centers on a sophisticated and nuanced approach to leadership, generative dialogues, and the creation of diverse networks able to ignite positive transformation in Silicon Valley.
	 
The Single Issue Education Classes will create a new and dynamic 21st century network of networks. This relationship-based network will place an emphasis on the quality of interactions and connections among its members. The network will create a container in which education leaders, forward thinkers, business pioneers, and passionate change makers will tackle the thorniest issues facing education in Silicon Valley. And it will be equipped to transform the ecosystem because of ALF’s unique process for creating transformative networks.
	 
The Single Issue Education Class is framed around the following questions:
	 
How will we take the best of what we have, transform the rest, and create an education system that inspires 21st century students to reach their potential?
How will we move what is standing in our way of a visionary future?â¨
How will we pave the paths to carry success from one place to another?
How will WE change, so that our children can fulfill their dreams?
	 
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
All authorized expenses as stipulated by the Board of Trustees
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
General Fund - Superintendent
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve the Superintendent to become a Fellow of the American Leadership Forum - Silicon Valley - as a Member of the Single Issue Education Class of 2013 as presented above.

SUBJECT:
Presentation, Discussion and/or Action of New Digital Teacher Signature for Attendance Reporting
			 
			 
California Department of Education approved the Digital Signature concept in 2009/10.  The District is ready for the implementation.  The teachers will no longer be required to manually verify attendance on the weekly paper report.  The implementation of the Digital Signature for attendance will save on staff time, paper, and ink cartridges for the printer.
			 
			 
FISCAL IMPACT:
Not Applicable

Not Applicable
			 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve the implementation of the Digital Signature for teacher attendance verification.

items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
			 
Item:  14.06
TO:
Board of Trustees
							 
FROM:  
							 
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
						 
						 
PREPARED BY:
Marcus Battle, Associate Superintendent of Business Services, and Charles Adams, Jones Hall
						 
						 
SUBJECT:
Adopt Resolution #2012/2013-15 Establishing Citizens Oversight Committee for Bonds Issued Under Measure I 
			 
At an election held on November 6, 2012, Measure I was passed by over 70% of the voters in the District, authorizing the issuance of $120 million of general obligation bonds by the District.  Under Proposition 39, the measure required an approval rate of at least 55% for passage.
			 
Under Section 15278 of the Education Code, the Board of Trustees of the District is required to establish and appoint members to an independent citizens' oversight committee within 60 days following the certification of the election results.  The purpose of the citizens' oversight committee is to review and report on the expenditure of the bond proceeds, and to advise the public as to whether the District is in compliance with the requirements of Proposition 39.
			 
The Board of Trustees has previously formed a Citizens Oversight Committee in connection with the bond authorization for Measure E at an election held on May 2, 2002.  Following the election held on February 5, 2008 in connection with Measure G, the Board of Trustees formed a separate Citizens Oversight Committee to oversee bonds issued under Measure G.  On February 19, 2009, the Board of Trustees merged the oversight committees for Measure E and Measure G into a single committee.
			 
In order to meet the requirements of the Ed. Code for Measure I, it is proposed that the existing Citizens Oversight Committee take on the additional responsibility for future Measure I Bond issues.  The attached resolution designates the existing Citizens Oversight Committee to have oversight responsibilities for Measure I Bonds, and amends the Bylaws of the Committee to implement Measure I.  The amended Bylaws also incorporate a recent amendment to the Ed. Code which permits members of the committee to serve for three consecutive terms.  Prior to the amendment of the Ed. Code, committee members could only serve two consecutive terms.
			 
FISCAL IMPACT:
As indicated in the attachment
			 
FUNDING SOURCE:
As indicated in the attachment
			 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees adopt resolution #2012/2013-15 Establishing Citizens Oversight Committee for Bonds Issued under Measure I.

EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
	 
Item: 15.01
	 
Amended
	  
TO:
Board of Trustees
					 
					 
FROM:  
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
					 
					 
PREPARED BY:
Marcus Battle, Associate Superintendent of Business Services, Linda da Silva, Director of Construction, Maintenance and Facilities, and Janice Unger, Capital Projects Purchasing Manager
					 
					 
SUBJECT:
Adopt Resolution #2012/2013-16 Authorizing Election under Public Contract Code Section 22030 to Become Subject to the California Uniform Public Construction Cost Accounting Act (CUPCCAA) Procedures
	 
This is a first reading of the California Uniform Public Construction Cost Accounting Act (CUPCCAA).  No Board action is required.
	 
The California Uniform Public Construction Cost Accounting Act (CUPCCAA) is a program created in 1983 by the State Legislature, which allows local agencies to perform public project work with alternative bidding procedures that expedite public works projects, yet maintains the spirit of open accountability.
	 
A local agency that has adopted CUPCCAA may procure public works projects as follows:
	 
(a) Public projects of $45,000 or less may be performed by negotiated contract or by purchase order (PCC 22032(a)). 
(b) Public projects of $175,000 or less may be let to contract by the informal procedures set forth in the Act (PCC 22032(b)).
(c) Public projects of more than $175,000 shall be let to contract by formal bidding procedures (PCC 22032(c)). 
	 
Every five years, the Commission shall consider whether there have been material changes in public construction costs and make recommendations to the State Controller regarding adjustments to the bidding procedure monetary limits (PCC 22020).  The most recent adjustment was made by the State Controller effective July 1, 2011.
	 
CUPCCAA is a voluntary program. A local agency becomes subject to CUPCCAA by adopting a resolution to become subject to CUPCCAA and filing a copy of the resolution with the State Controller's Office (PCC 22030).  An agency may withdraw at any time by filing a resolution of this election with the State Controller's Office.  There is no cost for adoption of CUPCCAA.
	 
	 
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
Not Applicable
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Not Applicable
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees receive the first reading of the California Uniform Public Construction Cost Accounting Act (CUPCCAA) and Resolution #2012/2013-16 Authorizing Election under Public Contract Code Section 22030 to Become Subject to the California Uniform Public Construction Cost Accounting Act (CUPCCAA).

Item: 15.02
Amended
	  
TO:
Board of Trustees
					 
					 
FROM:  
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
					 
					 
PREPARED BY:
Marcus Battle, Associate Superintendent of Business Services, Linda da Silva, Director of Construction, Maintenance & Facilities, and Janice Unger, Capital Projects Purchasing Manager
					 
					 
SUBJECT:
Adopt Resolution #2012/2013-17 Regarding the Enacting of Informal Bidding Procedures under the California Uniform Public Construction Cost Accounting Act
	 
	 
This is a first reading of the Enacting of Informal Bidding Procedures under the California Uniform Public Construction Cost Accounting Act (CUPCCAA).  No Board action is required.
	 
The District has elected to adopt the California Uniform Public Construction Cost Accounting Act procedures.  Alternative bidding procedures and certain informal bidding procedures will be implemented, in compliance with Public Contract Code 22030 et seq., for public projects of $175,000 or less.
	 
A list of contractors of the different categories of trade work that each contractor is qualified to perform shall be developed and maintained in accordance with Public Contract Code 22034.
	 
Where public projects are subject to the provisions of this policy, a notice inviting informal bids will describe the project in general terms and how to obtain more detailed information about the project, including the time and place for submission of bids.  The notice will be mailed to all contractors for the category of work to be bid as shown in the developed list of contractors, or all trade journals specified in the California Uniform Public Construction Cost Accounting Commission for Santa Clara County in accordance with section 22034 of the Public Contract Code, or both such contractors with such trade journals.  All mailing of notices to the contractors and/or trade journals described above shall be completed not less than ten (10) calendar days prior to the date that the bids are due.  Additional contractors and/or construction trade journals may be notified at the discretion of the Associate Superintendent of Business Services, and/or the Capital Projects Purchasing Manager provided that:
	 
          (1) If there is no list of qualified contractors maintained by the District for the particular category of work to be performed, the notice inviting bids shall be sent to the construction trade journals specified by the Commission and such other contractors and trade journals as the Associate Superintendent of Business Services and/or the Capital Projects Purchasing Manager may determine; and
          (2)  If the product or service is proprietary in nature such that it can be obtained only from a certain contractor or contractors, the notice inviting informal bids may be sent exclusively to such contractor or contractors.
	 
The Board of Trustees will award informal contracts pursuant to this policy.  If the lowest bid submitted by a responsible bidder exceeds $175,000, but does not exceed $187,500, the Board may nevertheless award the contract to such lowest responsible bidder if it determines, by 4/5th vote that the cost estimate of the public agency was reasonable.
	 
The Associate Superintendent of Business Services is authorized, without further action or authorization of the Board of Trustees, to award contract bids pursuant to the informal bidding procedures adopted by these resolutions pursuant to Public Contract Code Section 22034(e).
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
Not Applicable
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Not Applicable
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees receive the first reading of the enactment of informal bidding procedures under the California Uniform Public Construction Cost Accounting Act and Resolution #2012/2013-17 Regarding the Enacting of Informal Bidding Procedures under the California Uniform Public Construction Cost Accounting Act.

Item:  15.03
	  
TO:
Board of Trustees
FROM:  
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
PREPARED BY:
Marcus Battle, Associate Superintendent of Business Services, Linda da Silva, Director of Construction, Maintenance and Facilities,and Lorraine Guerin, Bond Program Deputy Manager, Seville Group, Inc.
SUBJECT:
Discussion and/or Action to Receive Report of Status of Measure G and Measure E, and Capital Improvement Program
	 
The District’s Capital Improvement Program is a complex portfolio of projects, spanning multiple years and funded by local general obligation bond measures A, G, E and I, OPSC school facility program grants, and other minor funding streams.  On September 20, 2012, Bond Program Manager Bob Bush presented an annual update of the bond program (see Attachment A).  This report provides additional information about current program activities and status.
	 
33 Measure E Phase 1 projects are in the process of being closed out.  Project closeout includes receiving final deliverables from vendors (contractors, architects, inspectors, testing labs, furniture/fixture suppliers, construction managers, etc.), making final payments and liquidating any excess financial commitments; finalizing labor compliance certifications; finalizing activities related to subcontractor and supplier payment certifications; a final project-level budget reconciliation and liquidation; and final records management activities.
5 Measure E Phase 1 projects are in construction.  We are using this opportunity to review standard procedures and activities that occur at or near the end of construction, to ensure a smooth handoff to operations and maintenance.  These include but are not limited to training administration and staff on the new facility and its security, lighting, mechanical and other systems; securing as-built drawings and specifications; securing Operations & Maintenance Manuals as well as spare parts/attic stock for equipment and products; and receiving warranty certificates, logs and procedural information.
17 Measure E Phase 2 projects are in the preconstruction phase, which includes programming, design, approval by the Division of the State Architect, bidding and contract award.  Budget reconciliation occurs during each of these phases of preconstruction.
1 Measure E Phase 2 project is in construction.   We are using this opportunity to review standard procedures and activities that occur during construction, to ensure safety and communication protocols are in place, to manage contract change orders, to ensure timely deliverables from professional service providers, and to plan subsequent activities such as FF&E provisioning, training and closeout.  
32 Measure G site improvement projects have been completed, and are in the closeout process.
We reviewed the remaining 75 Measure G site improvements projects against Measure E Phase 2 and Phase 3 projects to identify potential synergies, looking for opportunities to bundle work for efficiency.
We have identified procurement strategies and timelines to be used on the remaining Measure G site improvement projects.   Those strategies include design/bid/build, CUPCCAA informal bidding procedures, energy service and conservation contracts, and utilizing California Multiple Award Schedules (CMAS).  We anticipate numerous contract awards in the first half of 2013, with construction rollout thereafter.
	 
A status report is provided for your information (Attachment B).  The report includes information about the 163 current projects, funded by bond measures E, G, I and miscellaneous other minor funding streams.  The information is provided in dashboard format by site/program, and includes information on approved projects, budgets, funding sources, and status.
	 
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
N/A
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
N/A 
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees receive the Measure G and Measure E, and Capital Improvement Program status report.

Item:  17.02
				 
					 
TO:
Board of Trustees
					 
					 
FROM:  
Chris D. Funk, Superintendent
					 
					 
PREPARED BY:
Marcus Battle, Associate Superintendent of Business Services, Linda da Silva, Director of Construction, Maintenance and Facilities, and Janice Unger, Capital Projects Purchasing Manager
					 
					 
SUBJECT:
Receive Notice of Previously Approved Bid Award for California Environmental Quality Act (CEQA) Consulting Services
	 
	 
This information report is provided to advise that administrative staff will be executing a contract with David J. Powers & Associates, Inc., to conduct an initial study of the environmental impact of stadium lights at Santa Teresa High School, in compliance with the California Environmental Quality Act (CEQA).  This evaluation will serve to inform the District of any mitigation measures required in the design, construction or operation of the proposed lights.  
	 
All East Side high school stadiums have lights, except Silver Creek and Santa Teresa.  A CEQA initial study is already under way for stadium lighting at Silver Creek, and design services have recently commenced.  In order to bring equity of opportunity for stadium use to Santa Teresa High School by adding lighting for night time utilization, a CEQA initial study is a critical next step.
	 
David J. Powers & Associates, Inc. was selected as our primary CEQA consultant (RFQ-20-11-12; June 21, 2012 Board action).  A master agreement is in place with David J. Powers & Associates, Inc. for a period of one year beginning October 2012, with an option to renew for two additional one year periods.  A proposal from David J. Powers & Associates has been solicited and staff will report the contract amount on the February 2013 Purchase Order Report.
